intro: Oenothera gayophytum f. ramosissima, commonly known as the ramose evening primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its showy yellow to orange flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant has slender, branching stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are typically hairy. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in arid or semi-arid environments. The species is part of the Onagraceae family, known for its milky sap and diverse ecological adaptations.
